On May 6, 1933, a Nazi student group marched to the Institute for Sexual Science in Berlin. With members of the SA, they ransacked the institute and looted its library and archives. Breaking down instances by the number of users into bins (that are quasi human friendly logarithmic), we see that the majority (55%) have 2-50 users, ~33% have 1 user, and almost all instances have less than 5,000 users.

A lot of meta going around about the use of defederation recently, so let me chime in a little. Firstly:

Defederate the fash and harassers early and often. There's absolutely no reason to put up with them
Who small, friend-group instances choose to federate with is up to them. When you have 5 users, you're pretty much accountable only to them and it's easy to be accountable to them

With that out of the way, the complicated area where nobody can really agree on really lies in the middle. As an example, the people who threatened Matt Blaze's instance with defederation for criticising Mastodon's DM system didn't have some trust and safety issue in mind; they just had a beef. (And I don't think that one was serious, or would travel very far, but wielding it as a weapon like that is a rather ridiculous escalation from whoever was responsible for doing so)

@mekkaokereke used the term "HOA-style racism" to describe it, and I very much buy into that. An instance with a bunch of "just asking questions" sealions will putter along under the radar alienating users, while saying something that makes someone uncomfortable will get you yeeted into the sun.

There's a distinction between safety and comfort; and I feel like some of the moderation here conflates them. That's not to say that there's no purpose in making your place comfortable, but the two are not the same thing. People typically acknowledge that black people talking about racism is often unfomfortable but not unsafe, but I think theres a lot of other ares where people haven't.

As a tool for achieving safety (and complying with local laws...), the ability to cut all communication with another instance is vital. As a tool for achieving comfort, it's an overly blunt one.

(And also, it should go without saying: if your users are dogpiling someone, get them to cut that shit out)

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

From https://cheezburger.com/8991045120/understanding-art-lesson-one

It sounds trivial and obvious, but are you reading error bars correctly?

Do you know whether you're looking at standard errors (measures of inferential uncertainty), standard deviations (measures of spread of individual observations), or 95% confidence intervals around the mean?

And are your intuitions correct about how to interpret each of these?

Here's a nice primer, refresher, or teaching article.

https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.2659

h/t @jakehofman

Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback

SELF-REFINE, a framework improving LLM outputs using iterative feedback, emulates human text refinement. It doesn't need supervised training or reinforcement learning, functioning with one LLM. In 7 diverse tasks, SELF-REFINE surpasses direct generation, with outputs favored by humans and automated metrics, outperforming GPT-3.5 and GPT-4.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17651

title: Impact of OSS Courses on Student Self-Efficacy · It Will Never Work in Theory

last_post.content: Do courses that introduce students to open source make a difference? This new paper summarizes what we know: https://neverworkintheory.org/2023/05/07/impact-of-oss-courses-on-student-self-efficacy.html

title: Exclusive: The Silicon Valley quest to preserve Stephen Hawking’s voice

last_post.content:
Thinking, as I often do, about Stephen Hawking's voice, which began as a hardware synthesizer card connected to an Apple II and ended up as a software emulated version of that same card because he rebuffed all well-intentioned upgrades for 30 years because *it was his voice*.

https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/The-Silicon-Valley-quest-to-preserve-Stephen-12759775.php

“ What I hear in that is, “Those aren’t existential to me. I have millions of dollars, I am invested in many, many AI startups, and none of this affects my existence. But what could affect my existence is if a sci-fi fantasy came to life and AI were actually super intelligent, and suddenly men like me would not be the most powerful entities in the world, and that would affect my business.”

Great interview with @Mer__edith by @wilf
https://www.fastcompany.com/90892235/researcher-meredith-whittaker-says-ais-biggest-risk-isnt-consciousness-its-the-corporations-that-control-them

Hello! We're doing it!

Check out this preorder form for stickers and potentially greeting cards of my trans rights skull design (pictured below as a holographic sticker mockup): https://forms.gle/uFG4jZKwWAAKCw4A7

Any proceeds after materials and shipping are covered go to Rainbow Railroad: https://www.rainbowrailroad.org/

There may be form errors because I am one human doing my best - just message if so and I will do my best to fix them expediently.

I have no idea what to expect for volume on this, so please do bear with me if it explodes.

Boosts appreciated 🥰
#mastoArt #trans #transRights #transJoy

title: IBM CEO says employees' careers could suffer if they work from home

last_post.content:
“IBM chief says employees' careers could suffer and promotions may be harder to achieve if they work from home” https://www.businessinsider.com/ibm-ceo-remote-work-employees-careers-promotions-suffer-2023-5?amp

I'm going to show this quote from Manuel Lima's 'The New Designer' (https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262047630/the-new-designer/) to all my students from now on. Half of my semesters consists of feedback sessions and, no matter how kind and constructive these are, too many students feel wary about sharing their work in progress.

title: 6 reasons tooltips are a bad idea and what to do instead

last_post.content:
6 reasons tooltips are a bad idea and what to do instead (by Adam Silver): https://adamsilver.io/blog/6-reasons-tooltips-are-a-bad-idea-and-what-to-do-instead/
In the context of forms, I tend to agree here, show the hint directly instead of hiding it.
Unfortunately, sometimes the help is too long (hello enterprise forms). But, if you can't avoid tooltips, I recommend checking this to make them accessible: https://sarahmhigley.com/writing/tooltips-in-wcag-21/ (by Sarah Higley)
#Form #UX

6 reasons tooltips are a bad idea and what to do instead (by Adam Silver): https://adamsilver.io/blog/6-reasons-tooltips-are-a-bad-idea-and-what-to-do-instead/
In the context of forms, I tend to agree here, show the hint directly instead of hiding it.
Unfortunately, sometimes the help is too long (hello enterprise forms). But, if you can't avoid tooltips, I recommend checking this to make them accessible: https://sarahmhigley.com/writing/tooltips-in-wcag-21/ (by Sarah Higley)
#Form #UX

title: The use of AI-based tools (e.g. GPT) in JSBE as part of studies

last_post.content:
@algowatching
Jyväskylä University School of Business (Finland) was, I think, among the first to publish guidelines for ChatGPT and similar tools, back in January.
https://www.jyu.fi/jsbe/en/study/study-guide/administrative-rules-regulations-and-forms/the-use-of-ai-based-tools-e-g-gpt-in-jsbe-as-part-of-studies

Just heard a rumour that https://yarn.social is slowly rolling out support for #ActivityPub.

https://yarn.social is a decentralised and self-hosted social media platform based on the Twtxt format that has a privacy-first focus.

To find out what it looks like, here's an example of a yarn server:

https://twtxt.net

It's interesting to watch how other decentralized social networks adopt #ActivityPub.

@fediversenews

title: Texas Mass Shootings Up 62.5 Percent Since Permitless Carry Bill - Reform Austin

last_post.content:
"The math is even more damning when taking the number of victims into account. In the one-year period before the bill was signed, 187 people were killed or injured in mass shootings in Texas. In the one-year-after period, it was 375 people killed or injured, a 100 percent increase. Even if the 40 people killed or injured in the Robb Elementary School Massacre are excluded, the increase is 79 percent, an enormous jump in bloodshed."

Source: https://www.reformaustin.org/public-safety/texas-mass-shootings-up-62-5-percent-since-permitless-carry-bill/

title: Allen, TX Mass Shooter Posted Neo-Nazi Content, FBI Document Reveals

last_post.content:
Allen, TX mass murderer wore a “right wing death squad” patch

1. Armed w/an AR-15
2. A Nazi
3. Former US military
4. Radicalized on social media

#4 is why "algorithm choice" marketed by #Dorsey/#Bluesky is NOT a solution. Do you think if you don't see his posts, a radicalized right winger is less likely to murder?

His "social media accounts revealed hundreds of postings & images [&] writings with [racist] violent extremist rhetoric, including neo-Nazi materials"
